pull.title: miniscript: Use valid script in test, etc (#31713 follow-ups)
pull.body:
* Add missing move https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31713#discussion_r2722771821
* Document reason behind moving entire `vector`s https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31713#discussion_r2722932391
* Make miniscript valid and improve test name https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31713#discussion_r2722121348
* Check for miniscript node depth rather than script size https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31713#discussion_r2722062298

events.body: The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers. ### Reviews See [the guideline](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#code-review) for information on the review process. | Type | Reviewers | | ---- | --------- | | ACK | [l0rinc](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34499#pullrequestreview-3778205881) | If your review is incorrectly listed, please copy-paste <!--meta-tag:bot-skip--> into the comment that the bot should ignore.

I'm mostly okay with most of the changes, I don't like 0fcdd0d8221441fb2dd598a1a2a2b4378848c8e1, it kinda' throws out the baby with the bathwater. The old test ran everywhere and would still catch stack overflows - it just didn't guarantee it would fail for a broken implementation reliably.

Also, not sure when it's `uint32_t`, when `size_t` and when `long` - it should be unified.

events.message:
doc(miniscript): Explain why we operate on vectors

Explains the reason behind 198bbaee4959119a63b4038cd0dbb519f4daf6f0 where we had earlier switched from operating on unique_ptr<Node> to plain Node.

test(miniscript): Make tested script valid

Also give more appropriate name to test.

Co-authored-by: Antoine Poinsot <darosior@protonmail.com>

events.body: Latest push was based on feedback from https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34499#pullrequestreview-3749938660.

I'm currently evaluating a simpler approach to replace the previous 2 last commits (7e1d80f8eceb2db0c0461f3f1335e99b51c267c1 and b13c6ff9919e0f3a7fb117d85f93fb678cc01306) which introduced threads. Was planning to run it on a separate branch but accidentally pushed some test commits here. Moving to draft for now.

<!--85328a0da195eb286784d51f73fa0af9-->
ðŸš§ At least one of the CI tasks failed.
<sub>Task `macOS native`: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/actions/runs/21841872166/job/63028023404</sub>
<sub>LLM reason (âœ¨ experimental): Miniscript tests segfaulted (SEGFAULT) causing the CI to fail.</sub>

<details><summary>Hints</summary>

Try to run the tests locally, according to the documentation. However, a CI failure may still
happen due to a number of reasons, for example:

* Possibly due to a silent merge conflict (the changes in this pull request being
incompatible with the current code in the target branch). If so, make sure to rebase on the latest
commit of the target branch.

* A sanitizer issue, which can only be found by compiling with the sanitizer and running the
  affected test.

* An intermittent issue.

Leave a comment here, if you need help tracking down a confusing failure.

</details>

The current push (7a886f6b2a777df581b89f2fea803d315fe955b0) is ready for review despite the unrelated Windows CI issue. Compared to the last intentional push (b13c6ff9919e0f3a7fb117d85f93fb678cc01306 / https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34499#pullrequestreview-3750813111):
* Dropped the POSIX+Windows threading commits (see https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/34499#issuecomment-3874051875).
* Embedded a new comment in the currently last commit regarding the tests dependence on the stack being small enough relative the depth.
* Also amended the commit message to describe CI failures when running with naive `~Node()`.

This came after additional out-of-band feedback from @l0rinc and re-reading https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/31713#discussion_r2733647837 by @darosior, especially:

> I also think it's unnecessary to introduce more complexity here and it would be better to just document this test is only meant to reliably fail on CI, and it passing locally is not a guarantee that the author of a change did not introduce a bug there (unless they ran it under a low ulimit like CI does).

tree b4fad6facddbdbfc991c00969be1721da720e4de
parent 5af5e87646ec436bd4c86a62f70c376edb309ea9
author Hodlinator <172445034+hodlinator@users.noreply.github.com> 1770289335 +0100
committer Hodlinator <172445034+hodlinator@users.noreply.github.com> 1770719084 +0100

test(miniscript): Check for depth rather than script size

CI failure due to default ~Node() implementation has been confirmed on Windows native, MacOS native, 32-bit ARM, ASan+LSan+UBSan+integer, i686, TSan, MSan. (Not on Alpine as that runs without CI_LIMIT_STACK_SIZE).

Co-authored-by: Antoine Poinsot <darosior@protonmail.com>
Co-authored-by: LÅ‘rinc <pap.lorinc@gmail.com>

events.body: Latest push improves wording in new comment based in part on @DrahtBot feedback.

ACK 39e3295c71035b960bc9c5d0eeeaed3e06e9d1a6

rebased+tested locally, left a tiny nit, just close it if you disagree, it's not important.

comments.body: why is one depth a `long` and the other a `size_t`?

I'm not sure I understand this one. Instead of checking that the current code is working correctly on Windows, we exclude it completely because it wouldn't reliably fail for an incorrect implementation?
Taken, although I had to wrestle with the thread-lambda.
`PTHREAD_STACK_MIN` returns `long`, but I agree on striving towards `size_t` for more of the code.

~Windows doesn't respect the requested minimal stack space. I've implemented a workaround of munching up stack space using `alloca()` in latest push, let me know what you think.~

Edit: I wasn't using the right flag, the push contains a working reduced stack thread without `alloca()`. Above comment corresponded to a version I didn't push here.

Edit2: To be clear, I implemented Windows support in a separate commit. Let me know if you prefer it to be squashed together with POSIX.

nit: `auto` + `-> size_t` is a bit unorthodox, consider:
```suggestion
    const auto compute_depth{[] (const NodeU32& node) {
```
or
```suggestion
    const size_t compute_depth{[] (const NodeU32& node) {
```

Agree it's not common to specify the return type for such short lambdas, will try to remember to remove if I re-touch.
(The type of `compute_depth` is not `size_t`, it's a lambda, 2nd suggestion does not compile).
